fullText: This production achieves something that has eluded most revivals of this bewitching, problematic musical: it makes Sondheim's crystalline songs feel like natural expressions of a world in which sophistication is both a goal and a burden.
dtliExcerpt: This production achieves something that has eluded most revivals of this bewitching, problematic musical: it makes Sondheim's crystalline songs feel like natural expressions of a world in which sophistication is both a goal and a burden.
bwwExcerpt: Mr. Nunn’s “Little Night Music,” the first full Broadway revival of the show, may well be a hit too, though not because of any artistic finesse. It has what is a producer’s favorite form of insurance these days: stars known to the public from movies, television and tabloids, of whom people can later say things like “She’s even more beautiful in person” (as they surely will of the lustrous Ms. Zeta-Jones) or “She’s amazing for her age” (in reference to the 84-year-old Ms. Lansbury).
